translated: The Elder Nuns’ Birth Stories
The Elder Nuns’ Verses of the Therīs🔽The Chapter with Paṭācārā, Paṭācārā’s pupil, Sumedhā, Pañcadīpikā, and Paṭācārā’s pupil again
Pañcadīpikā’s Verses of the Elder Nuns
In the city of Haṁsavatī,
I was a wanderer at that time;
From monastery to monastery,
I wandered, seeking what is skillful.
On a day in the dark fortnight,
I saw the supreme Bodhi Tree;
Having inspired confidence there,
I sat down at the foot of the Bodhi Tree.

analyzed: garu cittam upaṭṭhetvā  sire katvāna añjali
translated: Having attended to the mind of the Buddha,🔽having raised my hands in respectful salutation,
having expressed my joy,
I thought like this at that time:
‘If the Buddha, of immeasurable virtue,
is without equal in the world,
may he show me a miracle,
may this Bodhi Tree be radiant.’
As soon as I had directed my mind,
the Bodhi Tree blazed up at that time;
it was all made of gold,
and all directions shone.
For seven days and nights,
I sat down at the foot of the Bodhi Tree;
on the seventh day,
I made an offering of lamps.
Having surrounded the seat,
five lamps blazed up;
as long as the sun rose,
my lamps blazed at that time.
By that good deed well done,
by the intention and the vow,
Having left the human body,
I went to the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.
There I did good deeds,
called the ‘Light of the Five Islands’;
Sixty leagues in height,
thirty leagues in breadth.
Innumerable islands
glow around me;
As far as the divine abode,
the light of the lamps shines.
Sitting with my face averted,
if I wish to see;
Above, below, and across,
I see everything with my eyes.
As far as I desire
to see the fortunate and unfortunate;
There is no obstruction there,
in trees or mountains.
Eighty kings of the gods,
I made great offerings to;
Of the mindful world-rulers,
I made great offerings to.
Wherever I am reborn,
as a god or a human;
Hundreds of thousands of lamps,

analyzed: parivāre jalanti me  deva lokā cavitvāna
translated: glow around me.
Having fallen from the world of the gods,🔽I was conceived in my mother’s womb;
While in my mother’s womb,
my eyes did not close.
Hundreds of thousands of lamps,
endowed with meritorious deeds;
In the lying-in room,
this is the fruit of the five lights.
When I attained my last existence,🔽I turned back the mind;
I experienced the ageless, deathless, cool state,
I experienced Nibbāna.
Seven days after my birth,
I attained Liberation;🔽The Buddha, having understood my virtue,

analyzed: guṇa maññāya gotamaḥ  maṇḍape rukkha mūle vā
translated: gave me the going-forth.🔽In a pavilion, at the foot of a tree,
in a room, or in a cave,
while living in an empty building,
the five lights shine for me.
My divine eye is purified,
I am skilled in concentration;
I have attained the perfection of knowledge,
this is the fruit of the five lights.
Having trained in all the trainings,
having done what had to be done, being without pollutants,
I pay homage at the feet of the Great Hero,
the Buddha, the Visionary.
For a hundred thousand eons,
the light I gave then,
I do not know of any bad destination,
this is the fruit of the five lights.
My defilements are burned up,
I live without pollutants.
Welcome indeed it was for me,
the Buddha’s instruction has been done.
The four analytical knowledges,

original: kataṁ buddhassa sāsanaṁ”.🔽Itthaṁ sudaṁ pañcadīpikā bhikkhunī imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.
analyzed: katam buddhassa sāsana  ittham sudam pañcadīpikā bhikkhunī imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati
translated: I have done the Teacher’s bidding.”🔽Thus have I heard.🔽The nun Pañcadīpikā recited these verses.
The Story of the Elder Nun Pañcadīpikā is the ninth.
